sourceDesc.p: Born digital. Information on original sources for transcriptions can be accessed via the transcriptions.

projectDesc.p: The Fortune Theatre Reecords: A Prototype Digital Edition is the outcome of a project exploring methods and means for the publication of Records of Early English Drama (REED) collections in a digital format.

editorialDecl.p: Do we want to use this for the Editorial Procedures section of the REED collection apparatus?

head.title: Extracts from the Dulwich College Audit Books

div.ab: Rents of the Fortune playhouse returned, nil Â£00..0.. 0the the: partially written over 0 two last times

head.title: Extracts from the Dulwich College Audit Books

div.ab:
Due to the College Â£19.141Â½. Arrears Â£1041..10..5.
owing the same Â£29 And Â£50 to Mr Lock, as above.
Memorandum The College entered upon the Fortune Playhouse Nov 21st the arrears having increased at aboue Â£64 half yearly till they reached the sum above stated viz Â£1041..10..5.
Since Edward Alleyn died on 25 November 1626, these extracts are from a continuation of his own account books.
What The fortune cost me
november 1599 1599: underlined

row.cell: first for ye leas to brew
then for ye building ye playhowe
for other priuat buildings of myn owne
so in all itt hath Cost me for ye Leasse

div.ab: bought the Inheritance of the Land of the gills of ye Isle of man which; is ye fortune & all the Howses in whight crosstrett & gowlding Lane in Iune 1610 for the some of 340 li.
' Brew' was probably Patrick Brewe, a cousin of the Gill family, who acted as their attorney.

head.title: Sir Henry Herbertâs Office Book
head.seg: Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library: Osborn Shelves d1.

div.p:
The
Troublesome Statesman Troublesome Statesman: underlined a new Play perused and allowed Jan 8, 1622â3; to be acted at the Fortune, by the Prince Palatine's servants, 1 li.

div.ab: The Palsgraves Players â A Trajedy of Richard the thirde or the English Prophett with the reformation contaynginge 17 sheetes written by Samuell Rowleye for the companye at the Fortune this 27th Iuly 1623 â 1 li.: 0.

head.title: Sir Henry Herbertâs Office Book
head.seg: Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library: Osborn Shelves d1.

div.ab:
This was done by the Lady Elizabeths servants att the Cockpitt ââ An olde Playe called the
Martir'd Soldier Martir'd Soldier: underlined formerlye allowed by Sir John Ashley but called in & reallowed with reformations: which were not observed, for to euery cross they added a star of their owne & for this cause I have thought fitt to peruse itt & to keep the booke for a president to the office and to take my fee this 23d August 1623.
(28 August) (Licence for a play)

Under another name that itt may pass the better Att the Intreaty of Mr Gunnell who prevailed with mee to gett the consent of Mr Biston Biston: underlined to the Cockpitt itt bears the name of the
Martir'd Soldier Martir'd Soldier: underlined this 28th of August 1623 â 1 li.

Palsgrave's men had acted at the Fortune playhouse , but this had been destroyed by fire in December 1621, when their losses included their play texts. After the Fortune was rebuilt in 1622, with Richard Gunnell as manager of Palsgrave's men, they would have been looking for replacement plays. He must have learnt that Herbert had decided to impound the play book of
The Martyred Soldier, and was now asking to put it on, albeit with Beestonâs permission (Bawcutt, Control and Censorship, p 144).

head.title: Sir Henry Herbertâs Office Book
head.seg: Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library: Osborn Shelves d1.

div.p:
A New Comedy
Hardshipe for Husbands ,Hardshipe for Husbands: underlined or Bilboes the best blade, containing 13 sheets, written by Samuel Rowley allowed October 29, 1623, for the Palsgrave's company.
div.ab: p 198 (4 December) (Licence for a play)
div.p: The Hungarian Lion ,Hungarian Lion: underlined written by Gunnell, licensed for the Palsgrave's Company 4 December 1623. 1 li.

div.ab:
For the Palsgraves Players November
A new Tragedye called 2 kings in a cottageg cottage: e written over a second g written by Bowen this 19th 1623 â 1 li.

For the Palsgrave's Company. Ianuary
The history of the Dutchess of Suffolk by Mr Drewe being full of dangerous matter was much reformed & for my paines this 2d Jan. 1623 I had 2 li.
Also noted by Malone in his copy of the play, Bodl.: Mal 190(3).

head.title: Sir Henry Herbertâs Office Book
head.seg: Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library: Osborn Shelves d1.

body.head: p 197* (6 January) ( Licence for a play)

div.p: The Foure Sons of Amon ,Foure…Amon: underlined att the intreaty of Worth, and another, being an olde Playe tho' never allowed of before, nor of a legible hand, with promise of my fee 6 Ianuary 1623, for Prince's Company 1 li. li.: underlined
div.ab: p 204 (26 January) ( Licence for a play)
div.p: The Whore in Grain ,Whore in Grain: underlined a Trajedy may be acted 26 Ianunary 1623â4. 1 li. For the Palsgrave's Company.

div.ab: The play was mentioned by Philip Henslowe in his Diary when he paid Shaa on behalf of the Admiral's men (then at the Fortune) on 10 December 1602 (probably in fact February 1602/3), 'for (vpon) a boocke,' Â£2. Shaa was possibly not the author of the play, which had already been performed by an English company at Amsterdam around 1601 (Greg, Henslowe's Diary, vol 2, p 227).

body.head: p 85 (6 April) ( Licence for a play)

div.ab:
For the Fortune â1624
A new Comedy called a Match or no Match written by Mr. Rowlye this 6th April 1624 â I li.
p 41 (17 April) ( Licence for a play)

For the Fortune â
The Way to content all Women or how a man may please his wife
written by Gunnell this 17 April 1624 â 1 li.

body.head: p 218 (3 May) ( Licence for a play)

row.cell: For the Prince's Company; A New Play, called, The Madcap: Written by Barnes.

div.p: Honour in the End, Honour…End: underlined Comedy conteyninge 12 sheets and half, allowed for the Palsgrave's company [21 May 1624 1 li. li.: underlined
div.ab: p 201 (27 May) (Licence for play)
div.p: TheParricide, Parricide: underlined containing 13 sheets and a half, allowed for the Princes Company 27 May 1624 4l?
div.ab: p 198 (July) ( Licence for a play)
div.p: Love me or Love me not, Love…not: underlined a new Comedy by Drew, allowed for the Palsgrave's Company Iuly 1624, 1 li. li.: underlined

div.p: The Honest Citizen, Honest Citizen: underlined an English History, by Deye, allowed for the Prince's Company, 14 July 1624 I li. li.: underlined
div.ab: p 195 (26 July) ( Licence for a play)
div.p: A Wedding, or a Cure for a Cuckold, Cure…Cuckold: underlined by Webster, allowed July 26th. 1624, for the Princes Company I li.

body.head: p 149 (15 September) ( Licence for a play)

div.ab: For the Palsgrave company â A Tragedy called the Faire Star of Antwerp 15th September 1624 1 li.
p 149 (15 October) ( Licence for a play)
For the Palsgrave company â A new Play called The Angell King 15 October 1624. I li.
p 149* (22 October) ( Licence for a play)

For the Palsgrave's company: A new Play, called, The Bristowe Merchant: written by Forde & Decker. 22 October
1624. 1 li.
p 149* (11 November) ( Licence for a play)
For the Palsgrave companyA new Play called the Masque 11th November 1624

The expansion of 'P' in Chalmers , Supplemental Apology, to ' Palsgrave's' is set against the expansion to ' Prince's' in Burn. The latter is probably correct, as Thomas Dekker was usually writing for either the Prince's company at the Red Bull, or the Lady Elizabeth's company at the Cockpit. The play was probably by Richard Gunnell and is now lost (Bentley, Jacobean and Caroline Stage, vol 4, 518â19).

body.head: p 131 (25 January) ( Licence for a play)

div.ab: For the Princes company A new Play called the Widowes prize contayning much abusive matter was allowed by mee on condition my reformations were observed 25 January 1624.

head.title: Account of London Companies and Theatres
head.seg: Malone: Plays and Poems, Vol 1, Part 2

body.head: p 101, n 1 (14 December) (French company of players)

div.ab:
"For allowinge of a Frenche companie att the Fortune to play one afternoone, this 14 of December 1629, â Â£l 0. 0.
"I should have had another peece, but in respect of their ill fortune, I was content to bestow a peece back." Ms. Herbert
Malone quotes here a section of Henry Herbert's Office Book that is now otherwise lost.

head.title: Sir Henry Herbertâs Office Book
head.seg: Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library: Osborn Shelves d1.

div.p: Merry Marriage Merry Marriage: underlined allowed to Fortune Company. Comedy 1630.

div.ab: The Merry Marriage is not otherwise known.

head.title: Account of London Companies and Theatres
head.seg: Malone: Plays and Poems, Vol 1, Part 2

div.p:
William was a student of Christ-chruch, Oxford, where he took the degree of Master of Arts in 1628. Soon after his father's death fatherâs death: John Hemmings, whose will was dated 9, and proved 11 October, 1630 he commenced a dramatick poet , having produced in March, 1632â3, a comedy entitled
The Coursinge of a Hare, or the Madcapp, The‖Madcapp: underlined 1, which was performed at the Fortune theatre, but is now lost.
div.ab: 1 Ms. Herbert.
Malone cites here a section of Henry Herbert's Office Book that is now otherwise lost.

body.head: p 46 (7 March) ( Lenten dispensations at the Fortune)

div.ab: From Vincent â For dancing on the Ropes this Lent at ye Fortune by Blagrave 7 March 1634 â 2 li.

William Vincent, alias Hocus Pocus, was the leader of a troupe of jugglers, conjurers, tight-rope dancers, acrobats, and sword-swallowers, and the most famous travelling entertainer of his day. In London, he lived in the parish of St Giles without Cripplegate, where the Fortune playhouse was sited, but was known in Leicester, Coventry, Oxford, and Norwich. For his career see N.W. Bawcutt, 'William Vincent, alias Hocus Pocus: A travelling entertainer of the seventeenth century,' Theatre Notebook 54 (2000), 130â8.

body.head: p 406 (12 May) ( Licence for a play)

div.p: "Received of ould Cartwright for allowing the [Fortune] [Fortune]: square brackets in original transcript company to add scenes to an ould play, and to give it out for a new one, this 12th of May, 1636, Â£. 1 0 0."

div.ab: Old ' Cartwright' was William Cartwright, the actor, who died in December 1686.

head.title: Sir Henry Herbertâs Office Book
head.seg: Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library: Osborn Shelves d1.

div.p: Dido and Æneas, Dido and Æneas: underlined allowed Queen's Company 1639.
div.ab: p 198 (Licences for a play)
div.p: The Jewell, Jewell: underlined a Com.edy Fortune, licensed 1639
div.ab: p 202 ( Licence for a play)
div.p: A Queen and No Queen, A Queen…Queen: underlined allowed to Fortune Company 1639
Woman Monster, Woman Monster: underlined allowed Fortune Company 1639

div.ab:
Dido and Ãneas was probably a new play, rather than the anonymous lost play of 1598 with this title. A Queen and No Queen is possibly Richard Brome's The Queen and Concubine (Bentley, Jacobean and Caroline Stage, vol 3, 85â6). The Jewell and
Woman Monster are not otherwise known.

head.title: Sir Henry Herbertâs Office Book
head.seg: Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library: Osborn Shelves d1.

div.p: The Humours of Rome, Humours of Rome: underlined made by a Schollar, allowed Fortune Company, 1640.

div.ab: The Humours of Rome is not otherwise known.

body.head: p 48* (23 June) ( Licence for a play)

div.ab: 23d Iune 1641 Received for the licensinge a booke for the Fortune company called the Doge & the Dragon. 2 li.
The Dog and the Dragon , by an anonymous author, is now lost.

head.title: Edmund Howes' Continuation of John Stowâs Annales

div.p: And about foure years after, a fayre strong new built Play-house, neere Gouldinglane, called the Fortune, by negligence of a candle, was cleane burnt to the ground, but shortly after, rebuilt farre fairer. In the yeare one thousand sixe hundred twenty nine there was builded a new faire Play-house, neere the white Fryers. And this is the seauenteenth Stage, or common Play-house, which hath beene new made within the space of threescore yeeres within London and the Suburbs, viz.

Fiue Innes, or common Osteryes turned to Play-houses, one Cock-pit, S. Paules singing Schoole, one in the Black-fryers, and one in the White-fryers, which was built last of all, in the yeare one thousand sixe hundred twentynine, all the rest not named, were erected only for common Play-houses, besides the new built Beare garden, which was built as well for playes, and Fencers prizes, as Bull Bayting; besides, one in former time at Newington Buts; Before the space of threescore yeares abouesayd, I neither knew heard nor read of any such Theatres, set Stages, or Play-houses, as haue beene purposely built within mans memory.

div.ab: The Globe burnt down on 1 August 1613, so this disaster was placed around or after 1617 ('four years after'); it was in fact December 1621. A 'new faire Play-house, neere the white Fryers' refers to the Salisbury Court playhouse.
